00063 /* Max number of GMXX */
00064 #define CVMX_HELPER_MAX_GMX (OCTEON_IS_MODEL(OCTEON_CN78XX) ? 6 \
00065                  : (OCTEON_IS_MODEL(OCTEON_CN68XX) ? 5 \
00066                     : (OCTEON_IS_MODEL(OCTEON_CN73XX) ? 3 \
00067                        : (OCTEON_IS_MODEL(OCTEON_CNF75XX) ? 1 \
00068                       : 2))))
00069 
00070 #define CVMX_HELPER_CSR_INIT0           0   /* Do not change as
00071                            CVMX_HELPER_WRITE_CSR()
00072                            assumes it */
00073 #define CVMX_HELPER_CSR_INIT_READ       -1
00074 
00075 /*
00076  * CVMX_HELPER_WRITE_CSR--set a field in a CSR with a value.
00077  *
00078  * @param chcsr_init    intial value of the csr (CVMX_HELPER_CSR_INIT_READ
00079  *                      means to use the existing csr value as the
00080  *                      initial value.)
00081  * @param chcsr_csr     the name of the csr
00082  * @param chcsr_type    the type of the csr (see the -defs.h)
00083  * @param chcsr_chip    the chip for the csr/field
00084  * @param chcsr_fld     the field in the csr
00085  * @param chcsr_val     the value for field
00086  */
00087 #define CVMX_HELPER_WRITE_CSR(chcsr_init, chcsr_csr, chcsr_type,        \
00088     chcsr_chip, chcsr_fld, chcsr_val)                                   \
00089         do {                                                            \
00090                 chcsr_type csr;                                         \
00091                 if ((chcsr_init) == CVMX_HELPER_CSR_INIT_READ)          \
00092                         csr.u64 = cvmx_read_csr(chcsr_csr);             \
00093                 else                                                    \
00094                         csr.u64 = (chcsr_init);                         \
00095                 csr.chcsr_chip.chcsr_fld = (chcsr_val);                 \
00096                 cvmx_write_csr((chcsr_csr), csr.u64);                   \
00097         } while(0)
00098 
00099 /*
00100  * CVMX_HELPER_WRITE_CSR0--set a field in a CSR with the initial value of 0
00101  */
00102 #define CVMX_HELPER_WRITE_CSR0(chcsr_csr, chcsr_type, chcsr_chip,       \
00103     chcsr_fld, chcsr_val)                                               \
00104         CVMX_HELPER_WRITE_CSR(CVMX_HELPER_CSR_INIT0, chcsr_csr,         \
00105             chcsr_type, chcsr_chip, chcsr_fld, chcsr_val)
00106 
00107 /*
00108  * CVMX_HELPER_WRITE_CSR1--set a field in a CSR with the initial value of
00109  *                      the CSR's current value.
00110  */
00111 #define CVMX_HELPER_WRITE_CSR1(chcsr_csr, chcsr_type, chcsr_chip,       \
00112     chcsr_fld, chcsr_val)                                               \
00113         CVMX_HELPER_WRITE_CSR(CVMX_HELPER_CSR_INIT_READ, chcsr_csr,     \
00114             chcsr_type, chcsr_chip, chcsr_fld, chcsr_val)

00141 typedef union cvmx_helper_link_info {
00142     uint64_t u64;
00143     struct {
00144         uint64_t reserved_20_63:44;
00145         uint64_t link_up:1;     /**< Is the physical link up? */
00146         uint64_t full_duplex:1;
00147                         /**< 1 if the link is full duplex */
00148         uint64_t speed:18;      /**< Speed of the link in Mbps */
00149     } s;
00150 } cvmx_helper_link_info_t;

00178 /**
00179  * cvmx_override_iface_phy_mode(int interface, int index) is a function pointer.
00180  * It is meant to allow customization of interfaces which do not have a PHY.
00181  *
00182  * @returns 0 if MAC decides TX_CONFIG_REG or 1 if PHY decides  TX_CONFIG_REG.
00183  *
00184  * If this function pointer is NULL then it defaults to the MAC.
00185  */
00186 extern CVMX_SHARED int (*cvmx_override_iface_phy_mode) (int interface,
00187                             int index);
00188 
00189 /**
00190  * cvmx_override_ipd_port_setup(int ipd_port) is a function
00191  * pointer. It is meant to allow customization of the IPD port/port kind
00192  * setup before packet input/output comes online. It is called
00193  * after cvmx-helper does the default IPD configuration, but
00194  * before IPD is enabled. Users should set this pointer to a
00195  * function before calling any cvmx-helper operations.
00196  */
00197 extern CVMX_SHARED void (*cvmx_override_ipd_port_setup) (int ipd_port);
00198 
00199 /**
00200  * This function enables the IPD and also enables the packet interfaces.
00201  * The packet interfaces (RGMII and SPI) must be enabled after the
00202  * IPD.  This should be called by the user program after any additional
00203  * IPD configuration changes are made if CVMX_HELPER_ENABLE_IPD
00204  * is not set in the executive-config.h file.
00205  *
00206  * @return 0 on success
00207  *         -1 on failure
00208  */
00209 int cvmx_helper_ipd_and_packet_input_enable_node(int node);
00210 int cvmx_helper_ipd_and_packet_input_enable(void);

00212 /**

00218  * @return Zero on success, non-zero on failure.

00220 extern int cvmx_helper_initialize_sso(int wqe_entries);

00249 /**
00250  * Initialize the PIP, IPD, and PKO hardware to support
00251  * simple priority based queues for the ethernet ports. Each
00252  * port is configured with a number of priority queues based
00253  * on CVMX_PKO_QUEUES_PER_PORT_* where each queue is lower
00254  * priority than the previous.
00255  *
00256  * @return Zero on success, non-zero on failure
00257  */
00258 int cvmx_helper_initialize_packet_io_global(void);
00259 /**
00260  * Initialize the PIP, IPD, and PKO hardware to support
00261  * simple priority based queues for the ethernet ports. Each
00262  * port is configured with a number of priority queues based
00263  * on CVMX_PKO_QUEUES_PER_PORT_* where each queue is lower
00264  * priority than the previous.
00265  *
00266  * @param node Node on which to initialize packet io hardware
00267  *
00268  * @return Zero on success, non-zero on failure
00269  */
00270 int cvmx_helper_initialize_packet_io_node(unsigned int node);
00271 
00272 /**
00273  * Does core local initialization for packet io
00274  *
00275  * @return Zero on success, non-zero on failure
00276  */
00277 extern int cvmx_helper_initialize_packet_io_local(void);
00278 
00279 /**
00280  * Undo the initialization performed in
00281  * cvmx_helper_initialize_packet_io_global(). After calling this routine and the
00282  * local version on each core, packet IO for Octeon will be disabled and placed
00283  * in the initial reset state. It will then be safe to call the initialize
00284  * later on. Note that this routine does not empty the FPA pools. It frees all
00285  * buffers used by the packet IO hardware to the FPA so a function emptying the
00286  * FPA after shutdown should find all packet buffers in the FPA.
00287  *
00288  * @return Zero on success, negative on failure.
00289  */
00290 extern int cvmx_helper_shutdown_packet_io_global(void);
00291 
00292 /**
00293  * Helper function for 78xx global packet IO shutdown
00294  */
00295 extern int cvmx_helper_shutdown_packet_io_global_cn78xx(int node);
00296 
00297 /**
00298  * Does core local shutdown of packet io
00299  *
00300  * @return Zero on success, non-zero on failure
00301  */
00302 extern int cvmx_helper_shutdown_packet_io_local(void);

00304 /**
00305  * Returns the number of ports on the given interface.
00306  * The interface must be initialized before the port count
00307  * can be returned.
00308  *
00309  * @param interface Which interface to return port count for.
00310  *
00311  * @return Port count for interface
00312  *         -1 for uninitialized interface
00313  */
00314 extern int cvmx_helper_ports_on_interface(int interface);

00316 /**
00317  * Return the number of interfaces the chip has. Each interface
00318  * may have multiple ports. Most chips support two interfaces,
00319  * but the CNX0XX and CNX1XX are exceptions. These only support
00320  * one interface.
00321  *
00322  * @return Number of interfaces on chip
00323  */
00324 extern int cvmx_helper_get_number_of_interfaces(void);

00327  * Get the operating mode of an interface. Depending on the Octeon
00328  * chip and configuration, this function returns an enumeration
00329  * of the type of packet I/O supported by an interface.
00330  *
00331  * @param xiface Interface to probe
00332  *
00333  * @return Mode of the interface. Unknown or unsupported interfaces return
00334  *         DISABLED.

00338 /**
00339  * Auto configure an IPD/PKO port link state and speed. This
00340  * function basically does the equivalent of:
00341  * cvmx_helper_link_set(ipd_port, cvmx_helper_link_get(ipd_port));
00342  *
00343  * @param ipd_port IPD/PKO port to auto configure
00344  *
00345  * @return Link state after configure
00346  */
00347 extern cvmx_helper_link_info_t cvmx_helper_link_autoconf(int ipd_port);
00348 
00349 /**
00350  * Return the link state of an IPD/PKO port as returned by
00351  * auto negotiation. The result of this function may not match
00352  * Octeon's link config if auto negotiation has changed since
00353  * the last call to cvmx_helper_link_set().
00354  *
00355  * @param ipd_port IPD/PKO port to query
00356  *
00357  * @return Link state
00358  */
00359 extern cvmx_helper_link_info_t cvmx_helper_link_get(int ipd_port);
00360 
00361 /**
00362  * Configure an IPD/PKO port for the specified link state. This
00363  * function does not influence auto negotiation at the PHY level.
00364  * The passed link state must always match the link state returned
00365  * by cvmx_helper_link_get(). It is normally best to use
00366  * cvmx_helper_link_autoconf() instead.
00367  *
00368  * @param ipd_port  IPD/PKO port to configure
00369  * @param link_info The new link state
00370  *
00371  * @return Zero on success, negative on failure
00372  */
00373 extern int cvmx_helper_link_set(int ipd_port, cvmx_helper_link_info_t link_info);

00375 /**
00376  * This function probes an interface to determine the actual number of
00377  * hardware ports connected to it. It does some setup the ports but
00378  * doesn't enable them. The main goal here is to set the global
00379  * interface_port_count[interface] correctly. Final hardware setup of
00380  * the ports will be performed later.
00381  *
00382  * @param xiface Interface to probe
00383  *
00384  * @return Zero on success, negative on failure
00385  */
00386 extern int cvmx_helper_interface_probe(int xiface);

00388 /**
00389  * Determine the actual number of hardware ports connected to an
00390  * interface. It doesn't setup the ports or enable them.
00391  *
00392  * @param xiface Interface to enumerate
00393  *
00394  * @return Zero on success, negative on failure
00395  */
00396 extern int cvmx_helper_interface_enumerate(int xiface);

00398 /**
00399  * Configure a port for internal and/or external loopback. Internal loopback
00400  * causes packets sent by the port to be received by Octeon. External loopback
00401  * causes packets received from the wire to sent out again.
00402  *
00403  * @param ipd_port IPD/PKO port to loopback.
00404  * @param enable_internal
00405  *                 Non zero if you want internal loopback
00406  * @param enable_external
00407  *                 Non zero if you want external loopback
00408  *
00409  * @return Zero on success, negative on failure.
00410  */
00411 extern int cvmx_helper_configure_loopback(int ipd_port, int enable_internal, int enable_external);

00431 /**
00432  * Convert Ethernet QoS/PCP value to system-level priority
00433  *
00434  * In OCTEON, highest priority is 0, in Ethernet 802.1p PCP field
00435  * the highest priority is 7, lowest is 1. Here is the full conversion
00436  * table between QoS (PCP) and OCTEON priority values, per IEEE 802.1Q-2005:
00437  *
00438  * PCP  Priority    Acronym     Traffic Types
00439  * 1    7 (lowest)  BK  Background
00440  * 0    6   BE  Best Effort
00441  * 2    5   EE  Excellent Effort
00442  * 3    4   CA  Critical Applications
00443  * 4    3   VI  Video, < 100 ms latency and jitter
00444  * 5    2   VO  Voice, < 10 ms latency and jitter
00445  * 6    1   IC  Internetwork Control
00446  * 7    0 (highest)     NC  Network Control
00447  */
00448 static inline uint8_t cvmx_helper_qos2prio(uint8_t qos)
00449 {
00450     static const unsigned pcp_map =
00451         6 << (4 * 0) |
00452         7 << (4 * 1) |
00453         5 << (4 * 2) |
00454         4 << (4 * 3) |
00455         3 << (4 * 4) |
00456         2 << (4 * 5) |
00457         1 << (4 * 6) |
00458         0 << (4 * 7);
00459 
00460     return (pcp_map >> ((qos & 0x7) << 2)) & 0x7;
00461 }
00462 
00463 /**
00464  * Convert system-level priority to Ethernet QoS/PCP value
00465  *
00466  * Calculate the reverse of cvmx_helper_qos2prio() per IEEE 802.1Q-2005.
00467  */
00468 static inline uint8_t cvmx_helper_prio2qos(uint8_t prio)
00469 {
00470     static const unsigned prio_map =
00471         7 << (4 * 0) |
00472         6 << (4 * 1) |
00473         5 << (4 * 2) |
00474         4 << (4 * 3) |
00475         3 << (4 * 4) |
00476         2 << (4 * 5) |
00477         0 << (4 * 6) |
00478         1 << (4 * 7);
00479 
00480     return (prio_map >> ((prio & 0x7) << 2)) & 0x7;
00481 }

00491 int __cvmx_helper_get_num_ipd_ports(int xiface);

00510 /*
00511  * @INTERNAL
00512  * Enable packet input/output from the hardware. This function is
00513  * called after all internal setup is complete and IPD is enabled.
00514  * After this function completes, packets will be accepted from the
00515  * hardware ports. PKO should still be disabled to make sure packets
00516  * aren't sent out partially setup hardware.
00517  *
00518  * @return Zero on success, negative on failure
00519  */
00520 int __cvmx_helper_packet_hardware_enable(int xiface);
